issues.title: RFC: Should we remove the 'good first issue' label?
issues.body:
Related to other discussions on low effort PRs #31679 and #32207

Should we remove the 'good first issue' label?

Note that we mention this label in the "[Issues for new contributors](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/21355)" section of the docs. It is also mentioned briefly at the end of the "[A typical workflow for triaging issues](https://scikit-learn.org/dev/developers/bug_triaging.html#a-typical-workflow-for-triaging-issues)" section.

Reasons for:

* currently there are no open issues with this label (https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues?q=is%3Aissue%20state%3Aopen%20label%3A%22good%20first%20issue%22)
* it is rare for good first issues to occur naturally. Often it requires maintainers specifically trying to think of one and spending time writing thorough details and guidance in an issue, probably what happens when searching for issues for people to work on in sprints, and even then, during the sprint, guidance is often required.
* it often attracts *many* low quality PRs - this is possibly because it's aggregated on sites such as https://goodfirstissue.dev/. It's difficult to find examples as we often remove the label but maybe #31318 and #30352 are examples of how much interest the label often attracts.
* it may be better for a user to start work on something that they use themselves and are familiar with, or something they already have background knowledge of. This would of course vary between people, making it a difficult label to use.
   * related, as described in @betatim's [post](https://discuss.scientific-python.org/t/what-does-it-mean-to-be-a-project-that-is-welcoming-to-newcomers/2127/3) on scientific-python, the type of users attracted to this label may be simply interested in getting a PR merged in a 'big' project. From Ralf: 'Promising new contributors are almost always motivated by a problem/topic, not by “getting on the scoreboard”'  
* for reference NumPy does not have a good first issue label (https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/21355) they do have a 'sprintable' label

This is just a request for comment, I understand if we decide to keep this label in the end.

cc @scikit-learn/core-devs

issues.title: ⚠️ CI failed on Linux_Runs.pylatest_conda_forge_mkl (last failure: Nov 09, 2025) ⚠️
Feature Request: Add explained variance ratios for X and Y to `PLSRegression`
issues.body:
### Describe the workflow you want to enable

Currently, `sklearn.cross_decomposition.PLSRegression` does not expose any measure of explained variance for either the predictor (`X`) or response (`Y`) spaces.

In different disciplines (such as multivartiate statistical process control, -omic sciences or chemometrics), the explained variance in `X` and `Y` spaces is a core interpretability metric and is routinely used to interpret PLS models — analogous to how PCA exposes `explained_variance_ratio_`. Not having access to it in the `PLSRegression` makes it difficult to:

- Quantify how much variance each latent variable captures,

- Compare models with different numbers of components, and

- Produce diagnostic or variance-explained plots (as is standard in different disciplines where latent space interpretability is important).


### Describe your proposed solution

#### Proposed solution

I propose adding two new attributes, automatically computed after fitting:

- `explained_x_variance_ratio_ `: `ndarray` of shape (`n_components`)
    Fraction of variance explained in X-space for each component.

- `explained_y_variance_ratio_ `: `ndarray` of shape (`n_components`)
    Fraction of variance explained in Y-space for each component.


These values are derived using standard PLS sequential deflation methodology (see Wegelin, 2000; Abdi, 2003), where variance explained = reduction in total variance after deflation per component, where each matrix is asymmetrically deflated per each component as follows:

$$X←X - \hat{X}_a = X - t_ap_a^T$$

$$Y←Y - \hat{Y}_a = Y - t_aq_a^T$$

This mirrors the `PCA` API (`explained_variance_ratio_`) and significantly improves usability for diagnostics and visualization.

#### Implementation sketch

```python
class PLSRegression(_PLS):
""" Documentation updated to include the follwoing attributes:

    Attributes
    ----------
    explained_x_variance_ratio_ : ndarray of shape (n_components,)
        Explained variance ratio in X-space (predictors) for each component.
        This measures how much variance in the predictor variables each latent
        variable captures. Calculated in fit().

    explained_y_variance_ratio_ : ndarray of shape (n_components,)
        Explained variance ratio in Y-space (response) for each component.
        This measures how much variance in the response
        each latent variable explains. Calculated in fit().
"""

    def __init__(self, ...):
        [this section is not modified]

    def fit(self, X, y):
        super().fit(X, y)
        # Calculate explained variance ratios
        (
            self.explained_x_variance_ratio_,
            self.explained_y_variance_ratio_,
        ) = self._calculate_explained_variance(X, y)

        return self

    def _calculate_explained_variance(
        self, X, y
    ) -> tuple[np.ndarray, np.ndarray]:
        """Calculate explained variance ratios using sequential deflation.

        This implements the variance decomposition for PLS regression following
        the deflation methodology described in Wegelin (2000).

        This method calculates how much variance each component explains by
        sequentially deflating the X and Y matrices. This is the standard
        approach in PLS and provides accurate component-wise variance.

        Parameters
        ----------
        X : array-like of shape (n_samples, n_features)
            Training vectors. Accepts numpy arrays, pandas DataFrames.
        y : array-like of shape (n_samples,) or (n_samples, n_targets)
            Target vectors. Accepts 1D (univariate) or 2D (multivariate) targets.

        Returns
        -------
        tuple[ndarray, ndarray]
            - X variance ratios of shape (n_components,)
            - Y variance ratios of shape (n_components,)
        """
        # Convert to arrays and ensure y is 2D (handles pandas DataFrame/Series)
        X = np.asarray(X, dtype=float)
        y_array = np.asarray(y, dtype=float)
        y = np.atleast_2d(y_array).T if y_array.ndim == 1 else y_array

        # Center X and Y (PLS already centers data, but we need the original centered versions)
        X_centered = X - X.mean(axis=0)
        y_centered = y - y.mean(axis=0)

        # Check for scaling
        if self.scale:
            # Scale to unit variance, avoiding division by zero
            X_centered /= np.maximum(X.std(axis=0, ddof=1), 1.0)
            y_centered /= np.maximum(y.std(axis=0, ddof=1), 1.0)

        # Total variance in centered data
        X_total_var = np.var(X_centered, axis=0).sum()
        y_total_var = np.var(y_centered, axis=0).sum()

        # Initialize matrices for deflation
        X_current = X_centered.copy()
        y_current = y_centered.copy()

        X_var_ratios = []
        y_var_ratios = []

        # For each component, calculate variance explained then deflate
        for a in range(self.n_components):
            # Get scores and loadings for component a (using slicing to keep 2D)
            t_a = self.x_scores_[:, a:a+1]  # (n_samples, 1)
            p_a = self.x_loadings_[:, a:a+1]  # (n_features_X, 1)
            q_a = self.y_loadings_[:, a:a+1]  # (n_features_y, 1)

            # Reconstruct X and y using current component
            X_hat = t_a @ p_a.T
            y_hat = t_a @ q_a.T

            # Variance of current residual before deflation
            X_var_before = np.var(X_current, axis=0).sum()
            y_var_before = np.var(y_current, axis=0).sum()

            # Deflate X and y
            X_current -= X_hat
            y_current -= y_hat

            # Variance of residual after deflation
            X_var_after = np.var(X_current, axis=0).sum()
            y_var_after = np.var(y_current, axis=0).sum()

            # Store variance explained as ratio of total variance
            X_var_ratios.append((X_var_before - X_var_after) / X_total_var)
            y_var_ratios.append((y_var_before - y_var_after) / y_total_var)

        return np.array(X_var_ratios), np.array(y_var_ratios)
```

#### Usage Example

```python
pls = PLSRegression().fit(X, y)
explained_x_variance = pls.explained_x_variance_ratio_
explained_y_variance = pls.explained_y_variance_ratio_
```

#### Testing

I have tested that this implementation provides the same results as the ones described by:

Abdi, H. (2003). Partial Least Squares (PLS) Regression. In Lewis-Beck M., Bryman A., Futing T. (Eds.), Encyclopedia of Social Sciences Research Methods. Thousand Oaks (CA): Sage.

I have also tested that this implementation does not break the `scikit-learn` estimator API:

```python
# Test compliance with scikit-learn
def test_compliance_pls_regression():
    # Arrange
    transformer = PLSRegression()
    # Act & Assert
    check_estimator(transformer)
```

### Next steps

If maintainers agree this feature fits within scope, I would be happy to:

- Open a PR adding the attributes to PLSRegression,

- Include updated documentation and examples, and

- Add unit tests verifying correctness against synthetic datasets and published examples.


### Describe alternatives you've considered, if relevant

_No response_

### Additional context

- No changes to existing API or behavior.
- Attributes are only added post-fit (similar to PCA’s `explained_variance_ratio_`).
- Could be extended to other PLS methods *(e.g., `PLSCanonical`) but it requires that other methods expose the `x_scores_` and the `y_scores_` (currently are not exposed) and to symmetrically  deflate the `Y` matrix.

### Previous issues

This request is not new, there were some previous. issues:

- https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/19896  (open but no  complete implementation suggested)
- https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/30470 (closed)

issues.title: load_iris example does not match text
issues.body:
### Describe the issue linked to the documentation

In https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.datasets.load_iris.html the example is introduced as "Let’s say you are interested in the samples 10, 25, and 50, and want to know their class name." 

However, the data indices are not used to index data.target_names in the code, so the code does not match the introduction.

Suggest changing the code to use the indices with output which is obviously what is expected.

### Suggest a potential alternative/fix

_No response_

issues.title: StandardScaler raises unclear error with empty feature names
issues.body:
### Describe the bug

When using StandardScaler with a pandas DataFrame that has empty strings as feature names (which can happen with certain data processing pipelines), the scaler raises a confusing error message that doesn't clearly indicate the root cause of the problem.

The error message should be more descriptive and guide users to fix the issue with their feature names.

### Steps/Code to Reproduce

```py
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler

# Create DataFrame with empty string as column name
df = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randn(10, 3), columns=['feature1', '', 'feature3'])

# Try to fit StandardScaler
scaler = StandardScaler()
scaler.fit(df)  # This raises an unclear error
```

### Expected Results

Either:
1. StandardScaler should raise a clear, informative error message like: "Feature names must be non-empty strings. Found empty string in column 1."
2. Or it should work by automatically handling empty feature names
3. Or raise a ValueError with a helpful message during validation

### Actual Results

KeyError: ''

The error message is not informative about what went wrong. It just shows that an empty string key was not found, without explaining that empty feature names are problematic.

### Versions

```shell
scikit-learn: 1.5.2
pandas: 2.2.0
numpy: 1.26.4
Python: 3.11.5
```

issues.title: DOC Create triage guide in maintainer documentation
issues.body:
As part of talking about triaging at the Scientific Python Summit I realised that we have quite some cumulative experience with triaging. There are also different approaches to things.

As a result I think it would be useful if we create a triaging guide as part of our developer/maintainer documentation. The goal of the guide would be to serve as a reference for what to do as a triager, what tools we have available to help with the process and so on.

Some initial things I can think of including:
* list of labels we have for triaging and what to use them for
* "please don't open a PR before the discussion has converged" as a policy (triagers should close these "early PRs" to help enforce this)
* bookmarked search queries/lists of issues
  * [needs triage](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues?q=sort%3Aupdated-desc%20is%3Aissue%20is%3Aopen%20label%3A%22Needs%20Triage%22)
  * [new PR without reviews](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pulls?q=is%3Apr+is%3Aopen+review%3Anone+sort%3Acreated-desc)
  * [new PR without reviews by a maintainer](https://github.com/search?q=repo%3Ascikit-learn%2Fscikit-learn+is%3Apr+is%3Aopen+author%3Abetatim+author%3Aogrisel+author%3Aglemaitre+author%3Alesteve+review%3Anone&type=pullrequests&s=created&o=desc)
     * needs more maintainer usernames in the query
     * we could have a similar query for recurring contributors, but how?
  * [PRs waiting for second reviewer](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pulls?q=sort%3Aupdated-desc+is%3Apr+is%3Aopen+review%3Anone+label%3A%22Waiting+for+Second+Reviewer%22)
  * [Open PRs that you have reviewed in the past](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pulls?q=sort%3Aupdated-desc+is%3Apr+is%3Aopen+reviewed-by%3A%40me+)

Can you think of more search queries that would be useful @lesteve?



xref https://github.com/scientific-python/summit-2025-nov/issues/6

issues.title: Reduce “Can I take this?” by front-loading /take rule
issues.body: ## Summary New contributors frequently comment “Can I take this?” on issues without the *help wanted* label. This creates notification noise and does not trigger CI assignment. The current contributing docs lead with “apply the ‘help wanted’ label to find issues… then comment `/take`”, which is easy to mislead as “`/take` is only for ‘help wanted’ issues”. ## evidence - **Maintainers have posted warnings like “comments such as ‘can I work on this’ or ‘assign this to me’ may get you banned” on issues already being worked on.** - **Recent examples of “Can I take this?” / “assign this to me” appear across issues.** (*The following images are only used to demonstrate the existence of this situation and have no other meaning.*) - **This noise hides actionable updates and shifts cognitive load to maintainers.** ## cause - The contribution guidelines are lengthy and detailed, which may make it difficult for beginners to quickly grasp the key points. If the opening example emphasizes a certain label, it can easily be misunderstood as "this is the only situation that can be done".In Contributing Doc,it emphasizes “help wanted” as the easy way to find issues and then says to comment `/take`. For some new contributer and skimmers, the mental model becomes: ***help wanted → allowed to /take; everything else → ask first***. - Many newcomers, out of politeness or lack of confidence, will first ask, "Can I do this?" to avoid doing something pointless or infringing on others' territory. This reflects their uncertainty about community norms. - The doc later explains time windows, stale/claimed PRs, etc., but many newcomers never read that. - Placing “filter by *help wanted* … then comment `/take`” early in the doc can plausibly mislead newcomers due to well-documented effects: [**Serial-position effect**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serial-position_effect?) makes early information disproportionately influential, so readers treat it as the operative rule;and the [**Web User Behaviour Directed by Information Scent**](https://www.interaction-design.org/literature/article/web-user-behaviour-directed-by-information-scent?) and the [**Default Effect**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Default_effect?) shows people often follow an implied “recommended” option when uncertain. Taken together, these explain why newcomers may ask “Can I take this?” on non-labelled issues. ## Proposal 1. **Front-load the universal rule right in the note box:** - “`/take` works for any unclaimed issue; the ‘help wanted’ label is only a discovery aid.” 2. **Add a one-sentence callout to discourage noise:** - “Please avoid comments like ‘Can I take this?’—use '`/take` instead. If you need design feedback, briefly outline your plan and then `/take`.” 3. **Link “how to check if an issue is already taken / time windows” from that same box.** ## Why do this? - This does not change policy; it clarifies and surfaces the existing policy. - No restructuring of the entire page—just a small copy edit and one cross-link. - Reduce the noise.

issues.title: Finish Python 3.10 -> 3.11 bump
issues.body:
> [!WARNING]
> This issue is already being worked on, a comment like "can I work on this" or "assign this issue to me" may get you banned from the repo
 
From git grep below
- [x] 3.10 -> 3.11 README.rst, pyproject.toml, meson.build, doc/developers/development_setup.rst 
- [ ] `update_environment_and_lock_files.py` the version is misleading, it should be 3.12.3 in Ubuntu Atlas. For completeness, this is the Python version to create the pip requirements lock-file.
- [x] Some possible clean-up in `sklearn/preprocessing/_encoders.py`
- [x] `.circleci/config.yml` probably not used much since we are using the conda env, either bump or remove
- [ ] maybe other things I have missed

```
❯ git grep -P '3\.10\b'
.circleci/config.yml:      - image: cimg/python:3.10.16
.github/workflows/check-sdist.yml:          python-version: '3.10'
README.rst:.. |PythonMinVersion| replace:: 3.10

sklearn/preprocessing/_encoders.py:    Python versions before 3.10. The handling of `nan` values was improved
sklearn/preprocessing/_encoders.py:    from Python 3.10 onwards, (c.f.
```

issues.title: CI cp313t intermittent failure `UserWarning: sklearn.utils.parallel.delayed should be used with sklearn.utils.parallel.Parallel`

labels.name: free-threading
labels.description: PRs and issues related to support for free-threaded CPython (a.k.a. nogil or no-GIL, PEP 703)

issues.body:
Also seen in https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/32303#issuecomment-3354667463 as well in a different test and on Linux (this one is on macOS).

This is very likely related to warnings being thread-unsafe in cp313t. Not sure this is worth doing something about it since it doesn't seem to happen that often.

```
  ______________________ test_no_user_warning_with_scoring _______________________
  joblib.externals.loky.process_executor._RemoteTraceback: 
  """
  Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "/private/var/folders/q1/lmdr88vx1k90l53fxl9p8lwc0000gn/T/cibw-run-kd2mu_4k/cp313t-macosx_arm64/venv-test-arm64/lib/python3.13t/site-packages/joblib/_utils.py", line 72, in __call__
```
